title-group.article-title: A study of human reaction during the initial stages of a dwelling fire using a Bayesian network model

article-meta.aff: 1Liverpool Logistics, Offshore and Marine (LOOM) Research Institute, Liverpool John Moores University, Liverpool, UK
2Merseyside Fire and Rescue Authority, Liverpool, UK

author-notes.corresp: Jin Wang, Liverpool Logistics Offshore and Marine Research Institute (LOOM), Liverpool John Moores University, Liverpool L3 3AF, UK. Email: j.wang@ljmu.ac.uk

abstract.p: Probabilistic modelling under uncertainty within the field of fire safety is examined in this article through the application of the Bayesian network technique. A Bayesian network model has been built to represent the initial stages of fire development within a dwelling and the associated events leading to human reaction. The model incorporates both hard and soft data, delivering posterior probabilities for selected outcomes. Case studies demonstrate how the model functions and provide evidence that it could be used for planning purposes and accident investigation. Finally, following a sensitivity analysis, discussion is undertaken on how the model could be further developed to investigate specific areas of interest and how they affect dwelling fires.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Man’s ability to control and harness the benefits of fire has led it to becoming part of our everyday existence. This in turn exposes us to a risk from fire in virtually every existing building and it is widely accepted that complete safety from fire is an impossible goal. Nevertheless, risk and uncertainty do not necessarily have to lead to uncontrollable situations that act against the wellbeing of people and progress of society. Anticipation of risk and appropriate responsive action can improve overall safety.

Fire risk assessment can be a complex task owing to the multiple variables and potential outcomes that must be considered. At a top level, fundamental topics of fire safety include prevention, ignition causes, fire detection, communication, human reaction, fire growth/containment, and emergency response, among others. Each of these topics is directly or indirectly linked to another in a cause–consequence type relationship in which the outcome of one particular topic affects that of a subsequent topic. For example, if fire detection is successful this may lead to or cause communication; if communication occurs then there may be human reaction, which may in turn lead to emergency response, and so on. The reality of fire safety is, however, far more intricate. Fundamental fire safety topics encompass a multitude of variables that influence each other in varying degrees. Taking assessment of human reaction as an example, consideration would need to be given to elements such as fire cues, human alertness, and mental and physical conditions. Sometimes other influencing variables may apply, such as time of day, time of year, weather, and so forth. Because of the multitude of interrelated variables, fire scenarios can be quite complex affairs. This makes assessing the magnitude of the next fire event and the likelihood of human reaction somewhat unpredictable, resulting in reasoning and decisions often taking place under uncertainty. In order to diminish some of this uncertainty and improve confidence in fire safety decision making, a Bayesian network (BN) is developed within this article focusing on the initial stages of a single occupancy dwelling fire; the model is built for application within the UK, but may be tailored for other locations with additional data gathering. The purpose is to model the sequence of events that may occur during the start of a fire at a given location, and to examine the critical variables that intervene in human reaction. This should assist in determining what the most important safety issues are for the purpose of improving fire prevention and mitigating consequences in order to reduce fire risk. Note that the intervention of fire and rescue services (FRSs) is not considered at this stage since the network is designed to represent a fire from the moment of ignition up to the instance of human reaction, that is, prior to any emergency ‘999’ call being made.
Before continuing, it is important to clarify the following frequently used terms.

list-item.p: Human reaction: this is when a person becomes aware of a fire and understands its significance; it does not represent the physical actions that may be subsequently undertaken.
Dwelling: this is a house used solely for living in; the term excludes caravans, make shift shelters, and buildings.

sec.title: Overview of UK fire fatality statistics
sec.p: Although fire safety within society has generally improved over recent years, progress must continue. In the UK fire still kills over 300 people and injures a further 9000 annually.1 A time-series of number of fire fatalities and dwelling fire fatalities is provided in Figure 1.1–4 There is a clear downward trend in both sets of data with total fire fatalities having fallen by 54.7% between 1996 and 2010, and dwelling fire fatalities by 54.6%. The third data set shown on the graph is the number of dwelling fires per fatality, obtained by dividing the number of dwelling fires by the number of dwelling fire fatalities. This gives an indication of how many fires need to occur before a fatality is registered. From Figure 1 it is evident that there has been a slight increase in this figure between 1996 and 2000, but from then onwards there has been little change; this indicates that the chance of surviving a dwelling fire, should it occur, has remained relatively constant between 2000 and 2010. In 2010 dwelling fires made up just 16% of all fires, however dwelling fire fatalities accounted for 79% of total fire fatalities. These statistics indicate that the significance of addressing dwelling fire fatalities is still very high.

caption.p: Number of fire fatalities and number of dwelling fires per fatality in the UK.

sec.title: Previous research
sec.p: Evidence suggests that modelling processes and events that may occur during a fire is hugely complex owing to the endless number of possible fire scenarios. A fire scenario is made up of influencing variables, such as ignition point, nature of fire, fuel configuration, number and location of occupants, characteristics of structure (size, escape routes, etc.), and ventilation, among others.5 It is evident that the fire scenario is critical in defining the outcome of a fire, a point also highlighted in research by Brannigan and Kilpatrick6 and Puchovsky.7

Because of their strengths for examining the outcome of situations under uncertainty, BNs have been extensively applied in a variety of disciplines such as medicine, finance, and computing. In industrial safety and risk, work has been undertaken by Hanninen and Kujala,8 Khakzad et al.9, Martin et al.10,Trucco et al.,11 Kannan,12 and Kohda and Cui,13 among others. Within the realm of fire safety BNs have been used for undertaking research on fire protection systems,14 modelling of structures under fire,15 human fatalities in fires,16 forensic investigation,17,18 and fire spread in buildings.19

Work by Hanea and Ale16 examines the risk to humans in building fires within densely populated and complexly designed cities such as those within The Netherlands. The research develops a BN designed to facilitate planning with regards to building location, structural design, and fire protection systems, based upon modelling percentage of fire deaths under given conditions. A planning tool based on a BN is essentially provided focusing on new yet-to-be-built structures rather than existing homes and buildings.

In other relevant research Holicky and Schleich14 present a BN mapped causally from fire start through to structural collapse of a building in order to analyse fire protection systems. The network includes elements of fire detection and automatic suppression, as well as a node representing fire brigade intervention; several utility nodes are also incorporated for cost-benefit assessment. Subsequent research by Holicky and Schleich15 provides a further developed model focusing on the cost of structural collapse and human injury/death resulting from fire. Decision and utility nodes are built into the network, which is used to provide risk profiles for structural collapse dependent upon different safety configurations.

Cheng and Hadjisophocleous19 deliver a BN for modelling the spread of fire from one compartment to another. This interesting approach commences by transforming the floor plan of a building into a directed acyclic graph with each compartment, stairwell, and elevator shaft represented by a node. Once the initial fire compartment is defined this general network is developed into a detailed model. Case studies are presented for a building with and without sprinklers.

Previous work focusing on the application of a BN to study dwelling fires has been undertaken by Matellini et al.5 The research presents a three-part BN model for different stages of a dwelling fire and subsequently develops part one. This research serves as the foundation for the present article.

sec.title: Building the model
sec.p: BNs provide a fitting way in which to model the relationship between variables within a given domain through the assignment and interlinking of nodes. The method allows for powerful graphic representation of a situation resulting from a series of causal events. Uncertainty between the multiple dependencies of nodes is captured through the assignment of conditional probabilities.

The key to building a BN capable of delivering meaningful results lies in its structure and input of data; thus a rational linkage of nodes and assignment of probability distributions is vital. With these assertions in mind, a BN was constructed using Hugin Researcher version 7.620 to model the events of fire in a generic dwelling from ignition through to the instance of human reaction.

To ensure a sound model was built, specialist knowledge was acquired by reviewing literature and gathering expert judgements. The model is designed to represent a fire incident in a generic dwelling; the term ‘generic’ is used since the model’s structure and data embodies conditions from the majority of homes. The primary reason for choosing dwellings as the subject matter was that most fires and fire fatalities occur there.1 Furthermore, in terms of total units, dwellings are the most common construction type and therefore will have significant impact on geographical fire risk distribution.

Attempting to build a model that would represent all dwellings would have been impractical owing to the complexity that would have been generated in trying to model the remaining minority of vastly different dwellings. It is important to emphasize that dwellings vary greatly in terms of size, design, building materials, fire safety measures, location, occupancy, activities within, etc., and representing all of this in a single BN would not be feasible. For this reason, the BN constructed is designed around a generic dwelling with the following characteristics.

list-item.p: Is between one and three stories high.
Has a maximum of ten bedrooms.
Has a maximum of one basement level.
Can be terraced, semi-detached, or detached.
Houses a mean of less than four people per bedroom.
Is used exclusively as a domestic residence.
Is primarily constructed from brick, stone, or concrete.
Is not a listed building.

sec.title: Nodes and structure
sec.p: The BN model (Figure 2) is designed to represent the initial fire development through nodes grouped into i) ‘initial circumstances’, ii) ‘fire cues’, iii) ‘human detection’, and iv) ‘output/human reaction’. The latter of these is considered the focus of the network and includes only one node, ‘Human reaction’ [states: Yes, No]. This chance node describes a human understanding the significance of a fire situation and reacting rationally. The assumption is that once a human is alerted, the chances of reacting are the same regardless of the way in which this happened. The reasoning behind a human not reacting is based on the possibility that he/she may be mentally or physically handicapped, thus he/she may not understand how to respond or may not be able to physically carry out any action.

caption.p: BN model representing initial fire development. Nodes are grouped into: i) initial circumstances; ii) fire cues; iii) human detection; iv) output/human reaction.

sec.p: There are 14 chance nodes in total labelled 1 to 14 and each has two states except for node 2 which has four states. The network was built based on expert judgement and subsequent discussion with FRS officers; several versions were experimented with before a decision was taken to proceed with the current version. In the network, root nodes generally form part of the existing circumstances during the fire, while chance nodes represent the events that could unfold during its development. Nodes in Figure 2 have been laid out chronologically from top to bottom. Events that can occur at roughly the same moment or that are similar have been positioned along the same horizontal line where possible and grouped as previously mentioned. The following lines describe each node and any associated assumptions.

list-item.p: Fire start type [states: flaming, smouldering] – this root node or parentless chance node represents the initiation of the fire that is either flaming or smouldering. Smouldering fires differ from flaming ones in that they produce smoke before visible flames; furthermore the smoke produced by smouldering fires tends to linger well below ceilings and contains relatively large particles. Flaming fires however develop much faster, releasing more heat and smoke than smouldering fires. Note that the type of fire that develops depends on a series of deterministic and random parameters. The reason these parameters are not modelled is because there are simply too many, there is little or no data available, and the model would not be improved because of the vagueness in dependencies between them and the type of fire.

Smoke alarm installed [states: yes –ionization, yes – optical, yes – combined, no] – this root node describes the presence of an automatic smoke alarm; a smoke alarm is a device inbuilt with both a smoke detector and an alarm. There are three types of smoke alarms: ionization, designed to detect flaming fires faster; optical, designed to detect smouldering fires faster, and; combined. The data for a combined smoke alarm also includes those dwellings that have both types of alarm.

Time of day [states: day 0700–2259, night 2300–0659] – this root node represents the time of day. There are two states set to reflect either a standard day span (0700–2259) for an adult or night span (2300–0659). A night:day ratio of 1:3 has been used based on the recommended 8 h of sleep for an adult.
Sprinkler installed [states: yes, no] – mirroring node 2, this root node describes the presence of an automatic heat activated sprinkler system.

sec.title: Fire cues (group ii nodes)

list-item.p: 5. Smoke alarm sound [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents the activation and acoustic propagation of the smoke alarm. Its conditional probabilities are set according to the state of its parent nodes 1 and 2.

6. Fire or smoke visible [states: yes, no] – this chance node describes the situation where fire and/or smoke are visible by a person before the fire reaches 1 m in diameter. This situation will likely be limited to the fire occurring within the same room as the dwelling occupant or within an adjacent room/corridor with open doors through which either a flickering of flames or spreading of smoke may be visible. A flaming fire will emit large noticeable flames and a great deal of smoke; a smouldering fire will have no flames and a lower rate of smoke production. Even though a smouldering fire may burn for longer, it is still less likely to be noticed. The conditional probabilities are set in relation to its single parent node 1.

7. Extensive smoke spread [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents the extent of spread of smoke particles throughout the dwelling. If smoke particles have spread from the room of origin while the fire is still smaller than 1 m in diameter then smoke spread can be considered extensive. It is important to note that smoke particles may disperse into compartments before the smoke itself becomes visible. This is why people often smell smoke before they see it. Conditional probabilities are set in relation to the state of its sole parent node 1.

8. Sprinkler activated [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents the activation of the automatic heat triggered sprinkler system, which entails water being sprayed throughout the dwelling. The conditional probabilities are set according to the state of its parent nodes 1 and 4.

sec.p: The four fire cue nodes presented above are not directly linked to each other, but they do share a common parent node, ‘Fire start type’. This means they can only influence each other through this node; thus, if evidence is obtained confirming the state of ‘Fire start type’, then the four fire cue nodes become conditionally independent of each other. Though the fire cue nodes are not directly connected, it could be argued that node 7 ‘Extensive smoke spread’ could also be a parent of nodes 5 ‘Smoke alarm sound’ and 6 ‘Fire/smoke visible’. However, the factors that may affect smoke spread, such as doors and windows being open, are already accounted for within the data for nodes 5 and 6; therefore, making such links would add no value to the model. Furthermore, node 7 is set out solely to represent the dispersion of smoke particles for the purpose of modelling the detection of fire through human smell (node 12). Node 7 is not a parent of node 6 because smoke particles are often not visible to the human eye.

list-item.p: 9. Human awake [states: yes, no] – this chance node describes the human condition of either being awake or asleep. The state of this node is affected by its single parent node 3 ‘Time of day’.

10. Human detection SOUND [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents a human detecting the fire by hearing the smoke alarm. The conditional probabilities of this node are set in relation to its parent nodes 1, 5, and 9. A human may also detect the fire through other noises, such as crackling, shuffling, and breaking of materials during combustion; since this is not represented through a separate node, a Leaky Noisy-OR gate is used in formulating the conditional probability table (CPT). The leak probability depends on the type of fire, reason for which node 1 is a parent of ‘Human detection SOUND’.

11. Human detection VISUAL [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents a human detecting the fire by seeing fire or smoke. The conditional probabilities are set in relation to its parent nodes 6 and 9.

12. Human detection SMELL [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents a human detecting the fire by smelling smoke. The conditional probabilities are set in relation to its parent nodes 7 and 9. Note that node 9 ‘Human awake’ is included as a parent of ‘Human detection SMELL’ based on the assumption that a person who is awake will also be mobile, thus there is a chance he/she could move to a location where the fire could be smelt, even though there has not been extensive smoke spread.

13. Human detection WET [states: yes, no] – this chance node represents a human detecting the fire by feeling the water from the sprinkler system. The conditional probabilities are set in relation to the parent nodes 8 and 9.

sec.title: Output/human reaction (group iv nodes)

list-item.p: 14. Human reaction [states: yes, no] – this chance node describes a human understanding the significance of a fire situation and reacting rationally. The assumption is that once a human is alerted (either through sight, sound, smell, or touch), the chances of reacting are the same regardless of the method. The reasoning behind a human not reacting is based on the possibility that he/she may be mentally or physically handicapped, thus they may not understand how to respond or may not be able to physically carry out any action. In putting together the CPT data the following exceptions had to be considered.
– Some mentally handicapped people have received specialist training on how to react in emergency situations.
– Some physically handicapped people might have someone with them at the time of the incident or may have an emergency call device to hand.

sec.p: The conditional probabilities of this node are set in relation to its parent nodes 10, 11, 12, and 13. Note that these probabilities do not vary with the number of parent nodes that have positive states, that is, one positive detection results in the same probability of human reaction as would two, three, or four simultaneous detections.

To check that the model has been simplified and that there are no superfluous nodes, d-separation tests were conducted using Hugin. Figure 3 shows d-separation in which the focus node is highlighted, the nodes which are d-separated (relevant to it) have a tick, and those which are d-connected (irrelevant to it) have a cross, in this case none. Other parts of the network have also been checked for respective relevance between nodes in a similar way.

caption.p: BN model showing d-separation for ‘Human reaction’.

sec.title: Data for the model
sec.p: Completing the probability table for each node required statistics and/or knowledge about the variable. For certain nodes difficulties were encountered regarding data being scarce, non-existent, based on small samples, old, and representative of varied geographical regions. Information and data fed into the model through marginal and conditional probabilities has originated from a variety of sources and in the majority of cases incorporates a degree of expert judgement. Table 1 summarizes the origins of data, the number of states, and the number of parent nodes for each node of the model. For cases when hard data was limited or could not be directly applied, expert judgement was used to tailor it to the current study. The ‘degree of subjectivity’ varies from case to case. Node 3 ‘Time of day’ for example contains relatively little subjectivity. In this case research indicates that adults generally sleep between 6 to 9 h per night, with young adults averaging 8 h,29 (cited in Encarta Enclyclopedia). Other studies vary slightly, for example Sukegawa et al.22 indicate that adults usually sleep 7 h per night. Since this node is one of the least influential within the model an approximate figure was all that was required, thus it was decided that 8 h or one-third of a day would be used as the figure indicating night or typical human sleep time. Another example of a node that combines literature with expert opinion is ‘Human awake’, which is based on information provided by Schur26 (cited in Night Owl Network).27 Schur26 states that according to most research the percentage of humans awake at night is 20%, though the text also points out that one leading researcher has the figure at 10%; Schur26 proceeds to challenge these figures indicating that it should be nearer 40%. In the BN a judgement was made to adopt the figure of 20% because it is supported by the majority of relevant research. An example of a node formed solely on expert judgement is node 4 ‘Sprinkler installed’. Since no published data exists, information was elicited from two experts involved in the residential fire sprinkler industry and a FRS officer. The first expert, the Secretary General of the British Automatic Fire Sprinkler Association, pointed out that less than 2% of dwellings have sprinklers installed (personal communication, telephone, December 2010). The second expert, a consultant at Domestic Sprinklers PLC., put the figure at around 1% (personal communication, email, December 2010), while the experienced FRS officer estimated it to be 1.5% (personal communication, interview, November 2010). All three experts were deemed to have a similar level of experience and knowledge of the subject reason for which the mean value (1.5%) was inserted into the node. Appendix 1 provides the marginal and prior conditional probability tables for all fourteen nodes.2,21,23–29

sec.title: Axioms for model validation
sec.p: A system of knowledge such as this BN model can be used to make a series of assertions. These assertions are essentially based upon a set of small understandable sentences, or axioms, which embody some of the underlying logic within the model. If a system is to provide reliable results it must first be shown to work rationally. Thus, in order to verify the reasoning behind the BN model, a set of axioms were defined and tested. In the statements, reference is made to the input nodes 1, 2, 3, and 4, which represent respectively ‘Fire start type’, ‘Smoke alarm installed’, ‘Time of day’, and ‘Sprinkler installed’. The focus node 14 ‘Human reaction’ is also included in some of the axioms. Reference is also made to groups of nodes as presented in ‘Nodes and structure’ and Figure 2. For the axioms below the following applies.

list-item.p: N denotes any node from 1 to 13.
F denotes the focus node 14.
I denotes an input node (node numbers 1 to 4).
u = [1, …, n] and v = [1, …, n] identify node numbers.
p and q identify number of nodes.

sec.title: Axiom 1
sec.p: A change in the probabilities of any node will influence the probability of the focus node and vice versa.

sec.title: Axiom 2
sec.p: Nodes that are closer to the focus node will have a greater influence on it compared with those that are further away; individual exceptions however can apply. Changes to nodes in group i) (nodes 1 to 4) will generally have a smaller effect on the focus node, compared with changes made in group iii) (nodes 9 to 13).
where the constants of proportionality k and c belong to R = (0,1) and k < c

sec.title: Axiom 3
sec.p: The more nodes featuring a posterior increase in probability, the greater the posterior probability increase for the focus node.

sec.title: Axiom 4
sec.p: The input nodes are independent of each other and therefore a change in one will not affect the others.

sec.title: Case studies
sec.p: It is important to stress at this stage that the numerical results of the model are not significant in an absolute sense, but rather serve to demonstrate the practicability of the model. The model has been used to study a series of possible real world scenarios. In each of the cases all variables remain unchanged except for those directly involved in the test. Posterior probability distributions are computed for likelihood diagnosis of nodes of interest given particular evidence. The focus of the model is human reaction to dwelling fires and the various situations in which this may arise, for example, the time of day when it occurs, the type of fire that develops, the presence of detection devices, etc. Three cases studies are now presented.

sec.title: Case 1 – Flaming versus smouldering fires, smoke alarms
sec.p: Flaming fires are intrinsically different to smouldering fires with the latter only being possible on porous solids such as cotton or polyurethane foam. Within dwellings the development and often the consequences of each type of fire can be quite different. The heat and carbon monoxide released from smouldering is far lower than from flames.30 Flaming fires develop very quickly giving off more heat and smoke, which rises rapidly to the ceiling. Flaming fires would thus appear more dangerous, however smouldering fires are far more difficult to detect unless suitable devices are installed. To this end this case study investigates the ability of humans to react to both types of fire before they have grown to be 1 m in diameter, after which escape is compromised.

The test involved investigating the impact of different types of smoke alarm on human detection through sound given a specific type of fire. To recapitulate, ionization smoke alarms are designed to respond faster to flaming fires and optical ones to smouldering fires. The bar chart shown in Figure 4 reflects this fact and highlights the relatively poor performance of ionization smoke alarms in smouldering fire situations compared with optical alarms in flaming fires situations. A human may also detect a fire through other sounds other than a smoke alarm; this is given by the ‘no alarm’ bars in Figure 4. In ‘no alarm’ situations it is evident that smouldering fires are harder to detect. If these two findings are coupled, a) ionization smoke alarms under performing in smouldering fire situations, and b) smouldering fires being harder to detect compared with flaming fires in the absence of an alarm, then the case for installing an optical alarm over an ionization one is justified from a technical stance. It is worth mentioning at this point that optical smoke alarms cost more than ionization ones. Thus the following question can be raised: Does the extra cost of an optical smoke alarm justify the potential benefits? This could be answered from the perspective of an individual who is considering installing a smoke alarm in his/her dwelling, or from the perspective of an organization like a FRS who have fire safety campaigns to plan.

caption.p: Posterior probabilities for ‘Human detection SOUND’ with evidence inserted for ‘Fire start type’ and ‘Smoke alarm installed’.

sec.title: Case 2 – Flaming versus smouldering fires, day/ night situation, alarm/no alarm situation
sec.p: This test compares human reaction during a combination of flaming and smouldering fire situations, occurring during the day and night, with and without smoke alarms. The ability of a human to react to a fire can be impaired during the night. It is also known that not having a smoke alarm significantly decreases the likelihood of early human reaction. The bar chart presented in Figure 5 combines these variables into four situations and applies them to both flaming and smouldering fire events to see how human reaction varies. The results show that not having an alarm dramatically decreases the chance of early human reaction, particularly for smouldering fires. Furthermore, for night time situations where there is no smoke alarm present, the probability of human reaction during a smouldering fire is nearly half compared with a flaming fire. Another important observation is the drop in human reaction during night time situations. This fact is already known, but an interesting finding is that the difference in human reaction probability between day and night situations is far greater when there is no smoke alarm present.

caption.p: Posterior probabilities for ‘Human reaction’ with evidence inserted for ‘Fire start type’, ‘Smoke alarm installed’, and ‘Time of day’.

sec.title: Case 3 – Causes of no human reaction
sec.p: The final case study analyses what occurs throughout the network when evidence is inserted into the focus node ‘Human reaction’. This could be used to assess a potential ‘real world scenario’ in which there has just been a dwelling fire and the occupant failed to react. In the case study it is assumed that the incident occurred during the night and evidence confirms that it started as a flaming fire. It is also known that a few days earlier the occupant installed a new optical smoke alarm; there is no sprinkler system in the property. An investigation is opened and the likelihood of the smoke alarm failing is analysed. The results are shown below through monitor windows displayed over the network (Figure 6). The posterior probability for node 5 indicates that the smoke alarm probably failed (59.8%). Such a finding is important since it could justify conducting an investigation into the origin of the smoke alarm. This simple case study demonstrates another way in which the model could be used.

caption.p: Monitor windows over the BN displaying likelihoods of why the occupant failed to react during the fire.

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: Model validation is conducted as follows with respect to the axioms described in ‘Axioms for model validation’.

sec.title: Axiom 1 and 2
sec.p: The probabilities of nodes 1 to 13 were individually varied in order to examine the effect upon the focus node ‘Human reaction’. For each node the probability of its first state was increased by an absolute value of 5% and the second state lowered by 5%. In the case of node 2 where there are four states, the other three states were decreased proportionally. The effect upon the likelihood of successful ‘Human reaction’ was recorded. Figure 7 presents the results using bars to display the individual effect of each node upon the focus node; a linear trendline has been added over the data. The bar chart confirms the validity of axioms 1 and 2.

caption.p: Bar chart showing how individual changes in nodes 1 to 13 affect ‘Human reaction’.

sec.title: Axiom 3
sec.p: To corroborate axiom 3 the probabilities of nodes 5 to 8 were increased by 5% and the effect upon the focus node recorded. The node increments were carried out one at a time but the effect upon the focus node aggregated. The results are shown in Figure 8; it is clear that raising the probability of a greater number of nodes increases further the probability of the focus node, thus confirming this axiom.

caption.p: Bar chart of ‘Human reaction’ state: yes, under different node probabilities.

sec.title: Axiom 4
sec.p: The probabilities of the input nodes 1 to 4 were individually varied by 5% to determine if they are independent of each other. Table 2 provides the results from which it can be seen that changes to a specific node do not affect the other nodes, which hence validates axiom 4.

caption.p: Table showing changes to the probability of the first state of each input node and its effect on other input nodes.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: Sensitivity analysis (SA) is fundamentally a measure of how responsive or ‘sensitive’ the output of a model is to variations in the inputs. Understanding how a model can respond to changes in its parameters is of great importance in maximizing its potential and ensuring correct usage. SA can also provide a degree of confidence that the model has been built correctly and is working as intended. In the context of this research, SA will be used to determine how responsive the output or focus node is to variations in other nodes. SA can also be viewed as a measure of dependence between selected input nodes and the output of a network. Knowing which nodes are the most influential can assist in experimentation, analysis, and further development of the model; nodes that are not important could subsequently be discarded or replaced.

SA has been conducted for the model to test the sensitivity of the focus node 14 ‘Human reaction’, to changes in the input nodes 1 ‘Fire start type’, 2 ‘Smoke alarm installed’, 3 ‘Time of day’, and 4 ‘Sprinkler installed’.

The parameter sensitivity wizard within Hugin was used to obtain a sensitivity value for each input node and a graph constructed (Figure 9) to display the results. From Figure 9 it can be seen that the most influential variable on ‘Human reaction’ was ‘Smoke alarm installed’, while the least influential was ‘Time of day’. If ‘Smoke alarm installed’ was to increase by 10% ‘Human reaction’ would increase by 2.2%; however if ‘Time of day’ was to increase by 10%, ‘Human reaction’ would only increase by 0.9%. The sensitivity values are also provided in Table 3; the higher the value the more influential the input node is on ‘Human reaction’.

caption.p: Sensitivity functions of four input nodes on the output node ‘Human reaction’.
Sensitivity values for four input nodes on the output node ‘Human reaction’. Input nodes have been ordered from most to least sensitive.

sec.p: The input variables involved in the SA are all root nodes. Of the four, only ‘Smoke alarm installed’ and ‘Sprinkler installed’ can be altered by reviewing fire safety arrangements. Based on the SA, from a human reaction perspective, it is evident that increasing smoke alarm installations within housing communities would be more effective than installing more sprinkler systems; costs are not taken into account at this stage.

sec.title: Further developments
sec.p: One of the advantages of BNs is that they can be expanded as more knowledge is gathered about a system. The model presented in this article is no exception and can be further developed to investigate in greater detail additional subjects. One expansion to the model is to turn it into a variable occupancy version. In reality the single occupancy BN is limited in application since the majority of dwellings have variable occupancy. Thus a pilot model has been developed with one additional node and connections made as indicated in Figure 10. The node description is as follows.

list-item.p: 15. Number of occupants [states: 0, 1, 2 to 4, >4] – this parentless chance node represents the number of people within the dwelling at the time of fire. Nominal information has been obtained from Communities and Local Government.31

caption.p: Variable occupancy version of BN model.

sec.p: Prior and posterior probabilities have been noted for human reaction with different levels of occupancy and are provided in Table 4. The prior probability from the single occupancy version of the model has also been included for comparison. It can be noted that both prior probabilities are very close indicating that the current single occupancy version of the model differs little from the variable occupancy version. This indicates that the single occupancy version is performing well in terms of final model outputs.

In other developments the model has been expanded to augment the analysis of the social aspect within dwellings. This is achieved through the addition of a node representing the ‘Index of Multiple Deprivation’ (IMD). These indices are the UK Government’s official measure of multiple deprivation at small area level.32 This index brings together 37 different indicators that cover specific aspects or dimensions of social deprivation. The indicators fall into the following categories: income, employment, health and disability, education, skills and training, barriers to housing and services, living environment, and crime. These indicators are weighted and combined to create the overall IMD. Reports have been published that link the index to the frequency of fires. Figure 11 provides a view of how the BN could be modified to include a social aspect. Four new nodes have been added for illustration purpose only headed up by the ‘Deprivation index’, which has also been connected to ‘Smoke alarm installed’ and ‘Sprinkler installed’.

caption.p: Modified version of BN model featuring four new nodes (highlighted): ‘Deprivation index’, ‘Weekend’, ‘Human sober’, ‘Human alert’.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A BN that models the initial stages of fire within a generic dwelling with a focus on human reaction has been presented. It has been argued that the diversity and complexity of fire scenarios makes them often unpredictable. On the back of this, the model has been used to demonstrate that BNs can provide an effective and adaptable method for determining the likelihood of events of interest under uncertainty. The model has been used to investigate the significance of fire types, smoke alarm, and the time of day, concluding that humans are less likely to react during a smouldering fire than a flaming one, but that this difference is far greater when there is no smoke alarm and it is night; for night time situations where there is no smoke alarm present, the probability of human reaction during a smouldering fire is nearly half compared with a flaming fire. A further case study demonstrates how the model is used during a fire investigation to determine causes of no human reaction.

The model can also be adapted to include additional nodes for investigating cases of variable occupancy and the impact of social deprivation upon human reaction. Furthering the applicability of the model can be achieved with relative ease based around its core structure.
